posts.name: Sparx
posts.cooked:
Hey there!

We have just finished writing our localization code! In our advantage scope, the robot’s filtered pose shows up and looks fine by us. Before starting autonomous commands, we want to check if our localization is actually accurate and we can trust it. Do you have any methods to check it? Until now we just measured the avg distance from the camera to the tag which is a pretty bold method.

So any methods?

link_counts.title: FRC Localization - How to check if your localization is accurate?

posts.name: Philip
posts.cooked: We have measured distances with a tape measure ie distance to target and if I move 5 ft does my localization say I moved 5 ft

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked:
We definitely do a straight line sort of (odometry only) test of about 10-15 feet with a tape measure.  Mainly to correct wheel diameter.

But checking logs on your filtered poses is something we do during field calibration.  Then use that to make any adjustments needed to camera transform needed to get the location lined up correctly.  For the most part we’ve made these adjustment by eye, seeing that the robot appears pretty much lined up.

Sometimes I’ve done repeated paths and marked ending location to see how close I could repeat 10 times or so.  Mainly I’ve done that with only odometry, but you could do with and without cameras.  I was thinking if you felt good with vision pose, you could use that to find your end position (while not using vision to update), to check how well you’re odometry was tracking alone.

It would be interesting to see what methods to check both accuracy and stability that others have been using to improve the localization and calibrations.

edit:  Last, I’ll note checking accuracy during competition can be even a bit more difficult to groundtruth, resorting to taking and pausing videos when you are at the various locations and seeing if parts of the robot chassis line up with field elements as expected.
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.name: Brian
posts.cooked:
ngreen:

We definitely do a straight line sort of (odometry only) test of about 10-15 feet with a tape measure. Mainly to correct wheel diameter.

We’ve done this a lot as well.

Recently, we started using angles from the gyroscope instead of a tape measure, so the process could be automated. Now we have an autonomous routine that slowly rotates the robot in place and compares gyroscope angles with drive encoder positions to calculate the diameter of each wheel. That takes about 30 seconds compared to the 5-10 minutes we had been spending on odometry calibration before.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: A nice why to check can also be to publish your odometry to some external dashboard like shuffleboard/smart dashboard/elastic etc, and watching you odometry as your robot drives around the field. Make sure there are no huge instant jumps and that your robot seems to always be in the right place as it drives.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: AdvantageScope has some good features for this, you can send it the pose estimates of all the tags the robot can see, so you can see what estimates are wrong.  I’ve also found it useful to publish both the “best estimate” fusing odometry and vision, and also the “raw vision input” pose which is noisier – again, so you can see more clearly what mistakes the vision system is making.

posts.name: Owen Flanagan
posts.cooked: Could you drop the code you use to do this? Sounds like a clean and elegant solution and I would love to steal… I mean, take inspiration from it.

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked: 6328’s wheel radius characterization is a great, fully-featured (if a bit complicated) example.
